Yes, there are several organizations working to improve the situation of mental health resources for refugees in Lebanon. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) has focused on promoting mental health for refugees since 2012, and the World Health Organization (WHO) provides guidance to healthcare workers in refugee settings.

The International Medical Corps (IMC) in Lebanon provides mental health services to Syrian refugees as well as some vulnerable Lebanese populations. Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) has also provided mental health services in Lebanon.

In addition, local NGOs such as Mousawat and Amel Association International also provide mental health services to refugees in Lebanon. These organizations are working within the community to provide awareness about the importance of mental health and to reduce the stigma associated with mental illness.

Despite the efforts by these organizations, more needs to be done to address the mental health needs of refugees in Lebanon. Sustainable funding and consistent attention to this issue are needed to improve mental health resources in the country.
